Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff gave youth edible and was transported to hospital due to
reaction.
Investigation On 6/28/23, I spoke to Administrator 1 via telephone.
Administrator 1 reported that Youth A and Youth B went to the
hospital after taking a marihuana edible. Administrator 1 reported
there were four staff on the unit at that time. Three of the staff
have been placed on administrative leave. Administrator 1
believes that Staff 4 gave Youth 1 the edible but Staff 2 and 3
were aware of the exchange. Administrator 1 reported she does
have video footage showing Staff 4 giving Youth A a book with
something inside of it.
Complainant 1 was contacted on 6/28/23 and provided no further
information.
On 6/30/23, I completed the following interviews at the
facility:
Administrator 1 reported that Staff 4 provided Youth A with a
book. Staff 4 did not have approval to give Youth A the book
making the transaction suspicious because it is the agency’s
practice that books cannot be given to youth with approval.
Administrator 1 reported that when she discussed the incident with
Staff 2, Staff 2 lied about the incident at first then acknowledged
Staff 4 brought the edible in and provided it to the Youth A in the
book. Administrator 1 reported that Youth A and Youth B ate the
edible and were throwing up. Administrator 1 reported that Nurse
1 checked on both youth and advised the agency to take them to
the hospital. Administrator 1 reported both youths went to the
hospital and Youth A refused to take the urine test. Youth B had
cannabinoids in his system.
Staff 1 reported she was assigned to the POD and Staff 3 was
working as well. Staff 4 came into the POD and handed Staff 3 a
book and then Staff 3 gave the book to Youth A. Staff 1 reported
that staff are not allowed to give youth items and Staff 4 should
not have given Youth A the book. Staff 1 reported there was
2

something in the book and it was not a bookmark. Staff 1 reported
the book was halfway open because of the item in the book. Staff
1 reported she left the POD at 2:00pm and was told that the youth
were sick later in the evening. Staff 1 then reported to Nurse 1
what had happened earlier in the day with the book. Staff 1
reported that Staff 4 is too friendly with the youth. Staff 1 reported
that Staff 3 was aware of what was in the book and didn’t say
anything.
Youth B reported he did receive the edible from staff. Youth A
would not report which staff did this. Youth A reported he ate the
edible around 1:45pm. Youth A reported around 3:00pm he was
feeling “weird” and couldn’t talk or walk normal. At 4:00pm they
went to dinner and then he went to the hospital.
Youth A reported he took an edible, threw up and then Nurse 1
saw him and sent him to the hospital. Youth A would not report
who provided him with the edible.
Staff 2 reported she was completing her rounds and was asked to
provide breaks to the staff on the POD. Staff 2 reported that she
did not see a book passed between staff and youth. Staff 2
reported she did not tell Administrator 1 that she saw them
passing a book. Staff 2 reported that she heard from Staff 3 there
was something in a book that Staff 4 gave to Youth A.
Staff 3 reported he was working on the POD when Staff 4 came
into the POD and gave him a book. He held onto it and then gave
it back to Staff 4. Staff 4 then gave Youth A the book. Staff 3
initially reported he didn’t feel anything the book yet disclosed to
DHHS Worker 1 that there was “candy” in it. Staff 3 reported he
didn’t say anything to anyone about the candy because he didn’t
“want anything to do with it.”
Staff 4 reported he was not supposed to be in the unit that he
went into the POD. Staff 4 reported he was assigned in a different
area but had a book for Youth A. Staff 4 reported he did not get
approval for the book. Staff 4 reported that he did not give Youth A
anything else but the book.
Youth B documentation:
I reviewed the Incident Report dated 6/27/23 at 4:45pm.
Document reports Youth B vomited on the floor and was seen by
Nurse 1 and then sent out to Detroit Receiving Hospital. He was
diagnosed with marihuana usage.
3

I reviewed the Detroit Receiving Hospital medical document for
Youth B. Youth B was positive for cannabinoids.
Youth A documentation:
I reviewed the Incident Report dated 6/27/23 at 5:15pm. Youth A
was nauseous and vomiting and transported to Nurse 1 then to
Detroit Receiving Hospital. It was noted that he had an “altered
mental status.”
I reviewed the Detroit Receiving Hospital document for Youth A.
He was diagnosed for “altered mental status”. Youth A refused a
urine test.
I reviewed the Professional Boundaries: Employee
Relationships with Youth Policy:
• “…a professional relationship implies that the relationship
does not extend outside professional duties and that all
planned interactions between staff and youth only occur
during the course of work and are authorized by the
treatment or service plan, and or agency procedures…”
• “Examples of Unprofessional Boundaries: buying and/or
giving gifts to youth that are unauthorized or outside the
scope of the program”.
• “…if an employee witnesses another employee behaving in
a manner that is contradictory to a professional relationship
and/or could be potentially detrimental to a youth, the
witness employee has a responsibility to report the
suspected behavior/relationship to the Program Director…”
Staff 3 was provided the following training:
Treatment overview, Policies and Procedures, Crisis Intervention,
Professional Boundaries (5/8/23)
Staff 2 was provided the following training:
Orientation/policies and procedures, Treatment Overview, Policies
and Procedures, Professional Boundaries,
Analysis Staff 4 provided Youth A with a book and “candy” when he was
not working with Youth A that day. These are outside the planned
interventions as noted in the Professional Boundaries Policy.
Administrator 1, Staff 1 and Staff 4 all confirmed that Staff 4 did
not have permission to give Youth A gifts. The candy that was
provided was a marihuana edible that caused nausea, vomiting,
disorientation and an “altered mental state” as noted in the
incident reports and Detroit Receiving Hospital.
4

Both Staff 2 and Staff 3 reported they knew Staff 4 gave Youth A
the marihuana edible but did not report this information to their
direct supervisor. Both failed to follow policies and procedure
designed to protect youth as required by this rule.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirement: staff qualifications.
Description (1) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(b) A check of Michigan’s child abuse and neglect central
registry or Canadian provincial agency referenced in R
400.4113(i)
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 4 provided Youth A with an edible marihuana candy and
Staff 2 and Staff 3 did not report this to supervision.
Investigation DHHS Worker 1 reported findings.
Staff 4 was provided the following training:
Youth Worker Treatment Functions, Crisis Intervention, Discipline
Techniques
Both Staff 2 and Staff 3 reported they knew Staff 4 gave Youth A
the marihuana edible but did not report this information to their
direct supervisor.
Analysis Staff 4 was provided training to perform the duties outlined for a
direct care worker and did not fulfill that role.
Staff 2 and 3 both reported they knew about the marihuana edible
and did not report this to their supervisor. They have been trained
on the policies and procedures which discuss how to intervene
when witnessing suspect behavior. They failed to follow policy.
Although trained on policy they do not have the ability to perform
the duties outlines. Another department in the state had findings
around this investigation.
Conclusion Violation Established

sir_summary.summary: A staff member at Lincoln Center gave a youth a book containing a marijuana edible, which the youth and another youth consumed, leading to hospitalization. Two other staff members were aware of the exchange but failed to report it, violating professional boundaries and supervision policies. The facility's administration is ultimately culpable for systemic failures in staff supervision and enforcement of policies that allowed this incident to occur.

sir_violation_level.justification: The report substantiates that Staff 4 gave Youth A a marijuana edible (candy) which caused nausea, vomiting, disorientation, altered mental state, and required transport to hospital. This involves medication errors, serious safety risks due to ingestion of harmful substance leading to hospitalization, and unmet treatment needs, aligning with the 'Medical and mental health concerns' category under severe SIRs.
